title: 114_s3160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Department" means the Department of State. "Infraction" and "violation" are defined as per Executive Order 13526. The "Inspector General" refers to the Inspector General for the Department of State. The term "Inspector General" in this Act refers to the Inspector General for the Department of State and the Broadcasting Board of Governors. The term "intelligence community" is defined as per the National Security Act of 1947. The term "Secretary" in this Act refers to the Secretary of State. SEC. 3. USE OF NONGOVERNMENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS. Employees of the Department must use only state.gov email accounts, Department-owned telephonic systems, or other Department-managed electronic communications systems for work-related communication. The Secretary must certify to Congress that all employees have access to these systems. The Secretary must certify to Congress that all Department employees have access to electronic communications systems. If certification cannot be made, a report must be submitted detailing the number of employees without access, reasons for the lack of access, steps taken to provide access, and measures to ensure reliable access. The Secretary of State must ensure that all Department employees have reliable access to work-related electronic communications and that these communications are appropriately recorded, archived, and reviewed for classified information. The Secretary may waive these requirements on a case-by-case basis for up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. The Secretary of State can waive electronic communication requirements for up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. All work-related communications must be archived according to federal regulations and justification must be provided to congressional committees. The Secretary of State can waive electronic communication requirements for up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. Waivers are valid for up to 180 days and can be reissued. The Secretary may issue multiple waivers if they align with the certification and justification. An oversight plan by the Inspector General will ensure accountability within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The oversight plan will ensure compliance with requirements by the Secretary and Department employees. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, with information on the responsible employee, date, and description of each violation. The annual report to Congress must include details on security violations, such as unauthorized transfer of classified information, the violated statute, and actions taken by the Department in response, including disciplinary measures and remedial training. If an employee with a violation history in the past 10 years is not terminated, the Secretary must request a review by the Federal Bureau of Investigations. The annual report to Congress must detail security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, violated statutes, and Department actions taken. If an employee with a violation history in the past 10 years is not terminated, the Secretary must provide a justification for not requesting an FBI review. The report must not be made public and must protect information under the Privacy Act of 1974. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. The Secretary appoints officials for training in detecting classified information spillage. Officials collect random email samples from employees with security clearances to detect spillage quarterly. The Inspector General audits the training program for detecting classified information spillage and includes findings in semiannual reports to congressional committees. SEC. 6. REMEDIAL TRAINING. The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed emergency refresher training on handling classified information, including rules for electronic transmission. The curr_chunk discusses various aspects of handling classified information, including communication methods, derivative classification, safeguarding information, handling foreign government information, processing FOIA requests, and challenges to classification status. The curr_chunk discusses challenges to classification status, protection of classified information, and requirements under Executive Order 13526. The curr_chunk outlines requirements under Executive Order 13526 for the successful implementation of programs handling classified information, including personal commitment from senior management, resource allocation, optimized record systems, designated officials, and evaluation of classified information management in personnel performance. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of evaluating personnel performance based on handling classified information, outlining penalties for violations and requiring employees to certify their understanding of rules and responsibilities. The Secretary prioritizes emergency refresher training for employees with different levels of security clearances, with the option to delay training for up to 30 days for specific individuals or groups. The Secretary can delay emergency refresher training for specific employees or groups for up to 30 days if critical foreign policy interests require it, with notification to congressional committees. "Applicable rules and procedures" include federal statutes, Executive Order 13526, other executive orders on classified information, and the Foreign Affairs Manual. The Secretary can delay emergency refresher training for specific employees or groups for up to 30 days if critical foreign policy interests require it, with notification to congressional committees. Additional guidelines include Executive Order 13526, other executive orders on classified information, the Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance or regulations. The Secretary must establish a training program within 180 days to prevent mishandling of classified information by Department employees. The program will cover proper handling of sensitive information and compliance with security standards. Additionally, a plan for reforming information requests and archiving will be developed. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days for completing reforms related to identifying classified information in documents under the Freedom of Information Act. This plan includes developing a training program for Department employees in coordination with the Director of National Intelligence. The plan must include procedures for officials from the intelligence community to determine the classification status of information. Additionally, a training program for Department officials on archiving electronic communications in compliance with relevant laws and regulations must be developed and implemented. The plan required under this section includes procedures for determining information classification status and a training program for Department officials on archiving electronic communications in compliance with relevant laws. Additionally, it mandates an annual sworn affidavit from each employee certifying the archiving of all documents in accordance with specific laws and regulations. The Inspector General will report to congressional committees on the Secretary's implementation of the plan within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must report to congressional committees on the implementation of the plan and progress in archiving and securing Department information.
